January 2018 | pmid = 29315690 | doi = 10.1002/pd.5195 | author1 = International Society for Prenatal Diagnosis | author2 = Society for Maternal Fetal Medicine }}</ref><ref name=":7" /> * Current pregnancy with an abnormal genetic screening test or test result<ref name=":10">{{cite journal | vauthors = Grody WW, Thompson BH, Gregg AR, Bean LH, Monaghan KG, Schneider A, Lebo RV | title = ACMG position statement on prenatal/preconception expanded carrier screening | journal = Genetics in Medicine | volume = 15 | issue = 6 | pages = 482–3 | date = June 2013 | pmid = 23619275 | doi = 10.1038/gim.2013.47 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = | title = Committee Opinion No. 640: Cell-Free DNA Screening For Fetal Aneuploidy | journal = Obstetrics and Gynecology | volume = 126 | issue = 3 | pages = e31–7 | date = September 2015 | pmid = 26287791 | doi = 10.1097/AOG.0000000000001051 }}</ref><ref name=":4" /><ref name=":8" /><ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Dondorp W, de Wert G, Bombard Y, Bianchi DW, Bergmann C, Borry P, Chitty LS, Fellmann F, Forzano F, Hall A, Henneman L, Howard HC, Lucassen A, Ormond K, Peterlin B, Radojkovic D, Rogowski W, Soller M, Tibben A, Tranebjærg L, van El CG, Cornel MC | display-authors = 6 | title = Non-invasive prenatal testing for aneuploidy and beyond: challenges of responsible innovation in prenatal screening. Summary and recommendations | journal = European Journal of Human Genetics | date = April 2015 | pmid = 25828867 | doi = 10.1038/ejhg.2015.56 }}</ref><ref name=":5" /><ref name=":6" /><ref name=":11">{{Cite web|url=https://www.acog.org/Clinical-Guidance-and-Publications/Committee-Opinions/Committee-on-Genetics/Counseling-About-Genetic-Testing-and-Communication-of-Genetic-Test-Results|title=Counseling About Genetic Testing and Communication of Genetic Test Results - ACOG|website=www.acog.org|access-date=2018-09-25}}</ref><ref name=":9" /><ref name=":7" /> * Current pregnancy with risk of or concern for maternal exposures, such as medications, radiation, drugs/alcohol, or infections *[[Consanguinity|Consanguineous union]] (cousins or otherwise blood related)<ref name=":11" /><ref name=":12">{{cite journal | vauthors = | title = Committee Opinion No. 690 Summary: Carrier Screening in the Age of Genomic Medicine | journal = Obstetrics and Gynecology | volume = 129 | issue = 3 | pages = 595–596 | date = March 2017 | pmid = 28225420 | doi = 10.1097/AOG.0000000000001947 }}</ref><ref name=":13">{{Cite web|url=https://www.acog.org/Clinical-Guidance-and-Publications/Committee-Opinions/Committee-on-Genetics/Carrier-Screening-for-Genetic-Conditions|title=Carrier Screening for Genetic Conditions - ACOG|website=www.acog.org|access-date=2018-09-25}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Bennett RL, Motulsky AG, Bittles A, Hudgins L, Uhrich S, Doyle DL, Silvey K, Scott CR, Cheng E, McGillivray B, Steiner RD, Olson D | display-authors = 6 | title = Genetic Counseling and Screening of Consanguineous Couples and Their Offspring: Recommendations of the National Society of Genetic Counselors | journal = Journal of Genetic Counseling | volume = 11 | issue = 2 | pages = 97–119 | date = April 2002 | pmid = 26141656 | doi = 10.1023/A:1014593404915 }}</ref> *Family history of an inherited genetic condition or chromosome abnormality * Genetic carrier screening for recessive and/or [[X-linked diseases]]<ref name=":10" /><ref name=":4" /><ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Rothwell E, Johnson E, Mathiesen A, Golden K, Metcalf A, Rose NC, Botkin JR | display-authors = 6 | title = Experiences among Women with Positive Prenatal Expanded Carrier Screening Results | journal = Journal of Genetic Counseling | volume = 26 | issue = 4 | pages = 690–696 | date = August 2017 | pmid = 27796679 | pmc = 5432405 | doi = 10.1007/s10897-016-0037-8 }}</ref><ref name=":12" /><ref name=":13" /> * History of a previous child with a birth defect, developmental delay, or other genetic condition<ref name=":4" /><ref name=":11" /><ref name=":12" /><ref name=":13" /> * History of infertility, multiple unexplained miscarriages or cases of unexplained infant deaths<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.acog.org/Clinical-Guidance-and-Publications/Committee-Opinions/Committee-on-Obstetric-Practice/Perinatal-Risks-Associated-With-Assisted-Reproductive-Technology|title=Perinatal Risks Associated With Assisted Reproductive Technology - ACOG|website=www.acog.org|access-date=2018-09-25}}</ref> *Molecular test for [[single gene disorder]]
Prenatal genetic counseling may help with the decision-making process by walking patients through examples of what some people might do in similar situations, and their rationale for choosing that option. Decisions made by patients are affected by factors including timing, accuracy of information provided by tests, and risk and benefits of the tests. This discussion enables patients to place the information and circumstances into the context of their own lives, and in the context of their own values.<ref name="pmid20235896">{{cite journal|vauthors=Stefansdottir V, Skirton H, Jonasson K, Hardardottir H, Jonsson JJ|date=July 2010|title=Effects of knowledge, education, and experience on acceptance of first trimester screening for chromosomal anomalies|journal=Acta Obstetricia et Gynecologica Scandinavica|volume=89|issue=7|pages=931–8|doi=10.3109/00016341003686073|pmid=20235896}}</ref> They may choose to undergo noninvasive screening (e.g. [[ultrasound]], [[triple screen]], [[cell-free fetal DNA]] screening) or invasive diagnostic testing ([[amniocentesis]] or [[chorionic villus sampling]]). Invasive diagnostic tests possess a small risk of [[miscarriage]] (1-2%) but provide more definitive results. Testing is offered to provide a definitive answer regarding the presence of a certain genetic condition or chromosomal abnormality.
=== Psychiatric genetics === Psychiatric genetic counseling is a sub-specialty within genetic counseling focused on helping people living with a [[Mental disorder|psychiatric disorder]] and/or their family members understand both the genetic and environmental factors that contributed to their illness and address associated emotions such as guilt or self-blame.<ref>{{Cite book|title=How to Talk with Families About Genetics and Psychiatric Illness|last=Peay|first=Holly|last2=Austin|first2=Jehannine | name-list-format = vanc |publisher= Norton |location= New York, London |year=2011|isbn=978-0-393-70549-2|pages=}}</ref> Genetic counselors also discuss strategies to promote recovery and protect [[mental health]] and address any questions on chances for recurrence in other family members. While currently there is no single gene solely responsible for causing a psychiatric disorder, there is strong evidence from family, [[twin studies]], and [[Genome-wide Association Studies|genome-wide-association studies]] that both multiple genes and environment interact together.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Giegling I, Hosak L, Mössner R, Serretti A, Bellivier F, Claes S, Collier DA, Corrales A, DeLisi LE, Gallo C, Gill M, Kennedy JL, Leboyer M, Maier W, Marquez M, Massat I, Mors O, Muglia P, Nöthen MM, Ospina-Duque J, Owen MJ, Propping P, Shi Y, St Clair D, Thibaut F, Cichon S, Mendlewicz J, O'Donovan MC, Rujescu D | display-authors = 6 | title = Genetics of schizophrenia: A consensus paper of the WFSBP Task Force on Genetics | journal = The World Journal of Biological Psychiatry | volume = 18 | issue = 7 | pages = 492–505 | date = October 2017 | pmid = 28112043 | doi = 10.1080/15622975.2016.1268715 }}</ref> Like other areas of genetic counseling, patients at all different stages of life (pediatric, adult, prenatal)<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Inglis A, Morris E, Austin J | title = Prenatal genetic counselling for psychiatric disorders | journal = Prenatal Diagnosis | volume = 37 | issue = 1 | pages = 6–13 | date = January 2017 | pmid = 27466037 | pmc = 5247258 | doi = 10.1002/pd.4878 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Ryan J, Virani A, Austin JC | title = Ethical issues associated with genetic counseling in the context of adolescent psychiatry | journal = Applied & Translational Genomics | volume = 5 | pages = 23–9 | date = June 2015 | pmid = 26937355 | pmc = 4745399 | doi = 10.1016/j.atg.2015.06.001 }}</ref> can have psychiatric genetic counseling. Since the etiology of psychiatric disorders is complex and not fully understood, the utility of genetic testing is not as clear as it is in Mendelian or single gene disorders.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Demkow U, Wolańczyk T | title = Genetic tests in major psychiatric disorders-integrating molecular medicine with clinical psychiatry-why is it so difficult? | journal = Translational Psychiatry | volume = 7 | issue = 6 | pages = e1151 | date = June 2017 | pmid = 28608853 | pmc = 5537634 | doi = 10.1038/tp.2017.106 }}</ref> Research has shown that individuals who receive psychiatric genetic counseling have significant increases in feelings of empowerment and self-efficacy after genetic counseling.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Moldovan R, Pintea S, Austin J | title = The Efficacy of Genetic Counseling for Psychiatric Disorders: a Meta-Analysis | journal = Journal of Genetic Counseling | volume = 26 | issue = 6 | pages = 1341–1347 | date = December 2017 | pmid = 28616830 | doi = 10.1007/s10897-017-0113-8 }}</ref>
Psychiatric genetic counselors can help "dispel mistaken notions about psychiatric disorders, calm needless anxiety, and help those at risk to draw up a rational plan of action based on the best available information".<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Tsuang MT | title = Genetic counseling for psychiatric patients and their families | journal = The American Journal of Psychiatry | volume = 135 | issue = 12 | pages = 1465–75 | date = December 1978 | pmid = 717559 | doi = 10.1176/ajp.135.12.1465 }}</ref>
== Psychosocial aspects of genetic counseling == There are different approaches to genetic counseling. Some counselors favor a more purely psycho-educational approach while others incorporate more psycho-therapeutic techniques. Genetic counseling is psycho-educational as patients "learn how genetics contributes to their health risks and then process what this means and how it feels."<ref>{{Citation|last=Biesecker|first=Barbara B | name-list-format = vanc |date=2016-08-16 |pages=1–5 |publisher=John Wiley & Sons, Ltd | doi=10.1002/9780470015902.a0005616.pub3 | isbn=978-0-470-01590-2 |title=ELS |chapter=Genetic Counselling: Psychological Issues }}</ref>
=== Psychotherapeutic === "Whether the process of genetic counseling is a form of [[psychotherapy]] is up for debate". The relationship between the client and counselor is similar as are the goals of the sessions. As a psychotherapist aims to help his client improve his wellbeing, a genetic counselor also helps his client to address a "situational health threat that similarly threatens client wellbeing". Due to the lack of studies which compare genetic counseling to the practice of psychotherapy, it is hard to say with certainty whether genetic counseling can be "conceptualized as a short-term, applied, specific type of psychotherapy". However, there few existing studies suggest that genetic counseling falls "significantly short of psychotherapeutic counseling" because genetic counseling sessions primarily consist of the distribution of information without much emphasis placed on explaining any long-term impacts to the client.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Biesecker B, Austin J, Caleshu C | title = Response to A Different Vantage Point Commentary: Psychotherapeutic Genetic Counseling, Is it? | journal = Journal of Genetic Counseling | volume = 26 | issue = 2 | pages = 334–336 | date = April 2017 | pmid = 27804046 | pmc = 5383505 | doi = 10.1007/s10897-016-0025-z }}</ref>
===Genetic counselors as support=== Genetic counselors provide supportive counseling to families, serve as patient advocates and refer individuals and families to community or state support services. They serve as educators and resource people for other health care professionals and for the general public. Many engage in research activities related to the field of medical genetics and genetic counseling. When communicating increased risk, counselors anticipate the likely distress and prepare patients for the results. Counselors help clients cope with and adapt to the emotional, psychological, medical, social, and economic consequences of the test results.
Each individual considers their family needs, social setting, cultural background, and religious beliefs when interpreting their risk.<ref name="pmid19711880">{{cite journal | vauthors = Dolan SM | title = Prenatal genetic testing | journal = Pediatric Annals | volume = 38 | issue = 8 | pages = 426–30 | date = August 2009 | pmid = 19711880 | doi = 10.3928/00904481-20090723-05 }}</ref> Clients must evaluate their reasoning to continue with testing at all. Counselors are present to put all the possibilities in perspective and encourage clients to take time to think about their decision. When a risk is found, counselors frequently reassure parents that they were not responsible for the result. An informed choice without pressure or coercion is made when all relevant information has been given and understood.
After counseling for other hereditary conditions, the patient may be presented with the option of having genetic testing. In some circumstances no genetic testing is indicated, other times it may be useful to begin the testing process with an affected family member. The genetic counselor also reviews the advantages and disadvantages of genetic testing with the patient.
===Attitudes toward genetic counseling and genetic testing=== Many studies have examined the attitudes of the lay public toward genetic counseling and genetic testing. Barriers to obtaining genetic counseling include lack of understanding of genetics by both patients and healthcare providers, concerns about cost and insurance, and fears of stigma and/or discrimination.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Gallagher TM, Bucciarelli M, Kavalukas SL, Baker MJ, Saunders BD | title = Attitudes toward genetic counseling and testing in patients with inherited endocrinopathies | journal = Endocrine Practice | volume = 23 | issue = 9 | pages = 1039–1044 | date = September 2017 | pmid = 28613942 | doi = 10.4158/EP171875.OR }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Haga SB, Barry WT, Mills R, Ginsburg GS, Svetkey L, Sullivan J, Willard HF | display-authors = 6 | title = Public knowledge of and attitudes toward genetics and genetic testing | journal = Genetic Testing and Molecular Biomarkers | volume = 17 | issue = 4 | pages = 327–35 | date = April 2013 | pmid = 23406207 | pmc = 3609633 | doi = 10.1089/gtmb.2012.0350 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Scuffham TM, McInerny-Leo A, Ng SK, Mellick G | title = Knowledge and attitudes towards genetic testing in those affected with Parkinson's disease | journal = Journal of Community Genetics | volume = 5 | issue = 2 | pages = 167–77 | date = April 2014 | pmid = 24018619 | pmc = 3955457 | doi = 10.1007/s12687-013-0168-7 }}</ref>
No simple correlation has been found between the change in technology to the changes in values and beliefs towards genetic testing.<ref name="pmid22476359">{{cite journal | vauthors = Singer E, Couper MP, Raghunathan TE, Van Hoewyk J, Antonucci TC | title = Trends in U.S. Attitudes Toward Genetic Testing, 1990-2004 | journal = Public Opinion Quarterly | volume = 72 | issue = 3 | pages = 446–458 | date = Fall 2008 | pmid = 22476359 | pmc = 3045776 | doi = 10.1093/poq/nfn033 }}</ref>
==International== In 2018, there are nearly 7000 genetic counselors practicing worldwide, across at least 28 countries.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Abacan|first=MaryAnn|last2=Alsubaie|first2=Lamia|last3=Barlow-Stewart|first3=Kristine|last4=Caanen|first4=Beppy|last5=Cordier|first5=Christophe|last6=Courtney|first6=Eliza|last7=Davoine|first7=Emeline|last8=Edwards|first8=Janice|last9=Elackatt|first9=Niby J.|date=2018-10-05|title=The Global State of the Genetic Counseling Profession|url=https://doi.org/10.1038/s41431-018-0252-x|journal=European Journal of Human Genetics|language=En|doi=10.1038/s41431-018-0252-x|issn=1018-4813}}</ref>
=== China === Genetic counseling in China (mainland) has been primarily provided by pediatricians or obstetricians for prenatal or birth defect diagnoses. Most genetic tests can only be performed in academic institutions as research tests or in commercial direct-to-consumer companies for non-clinical use.<ref name=":2">{{cite journal | vauthors = Zhao X, Wang P, Tao X, Zhong N | title = Genetic services and testing in China | journal = Journal of Community Genetics | volume = 4 | issue = 3 | pages = 379–90 | date = July 2013 | pmid = 23595912 | pmc = 3739851 | doi = 10.1007/s12687-013-0144-2 }}</ref>
In China, genetic counseling is steered by the '''Chinese Board of Genetic Counseling (CBGC)''',<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbgc.org.cn/en/|title=中国遗传学会遗传咨询分会|author=|date=|website=www.cbgc.org.cn|access-date=23 March 2018}}</ref> a not-for-profit organization. CBGC is composed of senior experts engaged in genetic education and research. CBGC is committed to establishing standardized procedures of genetic counseling, training qualified genetic counselors, improving health for all, and reducing the incidence of birth defects. CBGC was established in 2015 and is the major professional organization for genetic counselors in mainland China, providing training through short term online and in-person lectures, educational conferences, and certification for trainees.
Genetics education in China began in the 1980s when selected medical schools began offering genetics courses that focused predominantly on molecular genetics and had limited clinical content.<ref name=":2" /><ref name=":3">{{cite journal | vauthors = Li J, Xu T, Yashar BM | title = Genetics educational needs in China: physicians' experience and knowledge of genetic testing | journal = Genetics in Medicine | volume = 17 | issue = 9 | pages = 757–60 | date = September 2015 | pmid = 25503494 | doi = 10.1038/gim.2014.182 }}</ref> At present, there are no official master’s level graduate programs in genetic counseling or clinical genetics in China, and there is great variability in the duration and content of genetics curricula among medical schools and professional organizations.
The [[Ministry of Health of the People's Republic of China|Chinese Ministry of Health]] has not yet recognized genetic counselors as an independent health care occupation. There are no official statistics for the number of health care professionals (e.g., physicians, nurses, and lab technicians) who are providing genetic counseling services in China.
=== South Africa === Genetic Counselling is a developing field in South Africa.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Kromberg JG, Wessels TM, Krause A | title = Roles of genetic counselors in South Africa | journal = Journal of Genetic Counseling | volume = 22 | issue = 6 | pages = 753–61 | date = December 2013 | pmid = 23723047 | doi = 10.1007/s10897-013-9606-2 }}</ref> Currently, there are about 20 registered genetic counsellors practicing in the country. In South Africa, genetic counsellors work within academic institutions, in the private health sector and more recently, private genetic laboratories. A few qualified genetic counsellors have been employed outside of the country or in other professions, owing to funding limitations that have impacted employment opportunities, particularly in the academic/public health sector.
The first Genetic Counselling Programme in South Africa started in 1989 at the [[University of the Witwatersrand]] in Johannesburg, in the Gauteng province.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.wits.ac.za/course-finder/postgraduate/health/genetic-counselling/|title=Genetic Counselling - Wits University|last=Johannesburg|first=The University of the Witwatersrand,|website=www.wits.ac.za | access-date=2018-08-15}}</ref> A second programme started in 2004 at the [[University of Cape Town]] in the Western Cape province.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.humangenetics.uct.ac.za/hg/teaching/msc/courses|title=Genetic Counselling Courses {{!}} Division of Human Genetics|website=www.humangenetics.uct.ac.za | access-date=2018-08-15}}</ref> These are the only two programmes offering Masters level genetic counselling training in South Africa. Currently these courses are running at full capacity. This is a two year degree and includes a research component. The majority of students enter the Masters programme with a science background but those with a psychology background are also be considered.
The Health Professions Council of South Africa (HPCSA)<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.hpcsa.co.za|title=Home Page - HPCSA|website=www.hpcsa.co.za | access-date=2018-08-15}}</ref> requires two years of internship. Often the first year forms part of the Masters degree in Genetic Counselling and a further 12 month internship thereafter. Genetic Counsellors are required by law to register with the HPCSA in order to practice as genetic counsellors. At the end of the training period, registrants submit a portfolio to HPCSA for assessment. If successful, the intern will be registered with the HPCSA and will be able to practice as a Genetic Counsellor in South Africa.
There is a professional organisation for Genetic Counsellors in South Africa, '''Genetic Counselling South Africa (GC-SA),''' which provides information and guidance to the HPCSA and others regarding professional issues.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://sashg.org/about/focus-groups/genetic-counselling-south-africa/|title=Genetic Counselling South Africa – SASHG|website=sashg.org|access-date=2018-08-15}}</ref> The GCSA is a focus group of the South African Society of Human Genetics (SASHG).<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://sashg.org|title=SASHG – Southern African Society for Human Genetics (SASHG)|website=sashg.org|access-date=2018-08-15}}</ref>
=== United Kingdom === The majority of Genetic Counsellors in the UK work in the [[National Health Service]] (NHS)<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/genetics/services/|title=Genetic testing and counselling|website=nhs.uk|access-date=2018-08-16}}</ref> in one of the 33 Regional Clinical Genetics Services (some re-named Genomic Medicine Centres in England), Scotland, Wales or Northern Ireland. Others work in specialist roles in the NHS, education, policy or research. A minority work in the private sector.
The '''Association of Genetic Nurses and Counsellors (AGNC)''' is the UK's professional organisation representing genetic counsellors, genetic nurses and non-medical, patient-facing staff working within the discipline of Clinical Genetics.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.agnc.org.uk|title=Association of Genetic Nurses and Counsellors|website=www.agnc.org.uk | access-date=2018-08-16}}</ref> There are currently (March 2018) 330 AGNC members within the UK. The AGNC is one of the constituent groups of the British Society for Genetic Medicine (BSGM).<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bsgm.org.uk|title=British Society for Genetic Medicine|website=www.bsgm.org.uk | access-date=2018-08-16}}</ref>
The first 2 year MSc in Genetic Counselling program established in the UK was from the [[University of Manchester]] 1992, followed by [[Cardiff University]] in Wales in 2000. 2016 saw major changes in the way genetic counsellors are trained in England. A 3-year training programme funded by Health Education England, the Scientist Training Programme (STP) uses a combination of work-based training in Genomic Medicine Centres and a part time MSc in Genetics (Genomic Counselling) from the University of Manchester. Recruitment is performed nationally through the National School of Healthcare Science (NSHCS). A 3-year part time MSc in Genetic and Genomic Counselling is also now delivered by Cardiff University, through blended learning, with most of the teaching delivered online, alongside some short face-to-face teaching blocks in Wales. A 2-year MSc Genetic and Genomic Counselling program began at the [[University of Glasgow]] in Scotland in 2016. Prerequisites for acceptance on all the programmes include a degree in a relevant science or a nursing or midwifery qualification, and experience in a caring role. All genetic counselling training programmes are accredited by the UK Genetic Counsellor Registration Board (GCRB) and the European Board of Medical Genetics (EBMG).<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.eshg.org/index.php?id=113&L=0|title=European Society of Human Genetics: Training in Genetics|website=www.eshg.org|access-date=2018-08-16}}</ref>
Genetic counsellors in the UK are regulated through the Genetic Counsellor Registration Board (GCRB),<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.gcrb.org.uk|title=Home - Genetic Counsellor Registration Board|website=Genetic Counsellor Registration Board | access-date=2018-08-16}}</ref> although currently GCRB registration is voluntary.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Ormond KE, Laurino MY, Barlow-Stewart K, Wessels TM, Macaulay S, Austin J, Middleton A | title = Genetic counseling globally: Where are we now? | journal = American Journal of Medical Genetics Part C: Seminars in Medical Genetics | volume = 178 | issue = 1 | pages = 98–107 | date = March 2018 | pmid = 29575600 | pmc = 5947883 | doi = 10.1002/ajmg.c.31607 }}</ref> The GCRB registry was accredited in 2016 by the Professional Standards Authority under its Accredited Registers programme. Over 200 genetic counsellors are currently registered through the GCRB. Genetic Counsellors trained through the STP programme are expected to be eligible to apply for statutory regulation through the Health Care Professions Council and it is planned that soon there will be equivalence arrangements with the GCRB to ensure statutory regulation for GCRB registered genetic counsellors.

{{see also|George Town, Penang}} [[File:Beach Street Penang Dec 2006 009.jpg|thumb|[[Standard Chartered]] Building at [[Beach Street, George Town|Beach Street]], [[George Town, Penang|George Town]]. The [[Jubilee Clock Tower|Queen Victoria Memorial Clock Tower]] can be seen down the road.]] The '''George Town CBD''' is the [[central business district]] within [[George Town, Penang|George Town]], the capital city of the state of [[Penang]] in [[Malaysia]]. As the term implies, the CBD contains the highest concentration of financial and banking services within [[George Town, Penang|George Town]], serving as the city's financial heart. [[File:Gurney Drive, George Town in 2018.jpg|left|thumb|[[Gurney Drive, George Town|Gurney Drive]] forms part of [[George Town, Penang|George Town]]'s second CBD]] Traditionally, [[Beach Street, George Town|Beach Street]] has been regarded as the [[central business district]] of [[George Town, Penang|George Town]]. One of the first streets to be created in [[Penang]], [[Beach Street, George Town|Beach Street]] was where several international banks built their branches in the late 19th century. To this day, many of the banks remain along the street. In addition, within the vicinity of [[Beach Street, George Town|Beach Street]], governmental buildings were constructed, making the area the administrative centre of [[Penang]] for much of the [[History of Penang|state's history]].
In recent decades, various banking, financial and auditing services have been concentrated at [[Northam Road, George Town|Northam Road]] as well, turning the road into [[George Town, Penang|George Town]]'s second CBD.<ref name=":02">{{Cite web|url=https://www.thestar.com.my/business/business-news/2003/12/15/penangs-new-financial-hub/|title=Penang’s new financial hub - Business News {{!}} The Star Online|website=www.thestar.com.my|access-date=2017-11-18}}</ref> The adjoining [[Gurney Drive]], with a high concentration of skyscrapers, also forms part of the city's newer CBD.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=http://www.themalaymailonline.com/malaysia/article/penang-dap-rep-put-all-projects-in-gurney-drive-on-hold|title=Penang DAP rep: Put all projects in Gurney Drive on hold|date=2015-05-22|access-date=2016-11-27}}</ref>
== Historic CBD: [[Beach Street, George Town|Beach Street]] == {{see also|Beach Street, George Town}} [[File:The Map of Early Penang Showing the Malay Town on the South of the Town Center by Popham 1799.jpg|thumb|[[Light Street, George Town, Penang|Light Street]] (along the south of [[Fort Cornwallis]]) and [[Beach Street, George Town|Beach Street]] can be seen in this 1799 map of [[George Town, Penang|George Town]].]] Historically, this district coincides with the particular area that was first explored and developed by Captain [[Francis Light]] after his founding of [[Penang]] in 1786. It is centred at [[Beach Street, George Town|Beach Street]] and [[Light Street, George Town, Penang|Light Street]], which are among the first streets to be created on [[Penang Island]]. It is loosely bounded by [[Pitt Street, George Town|Pitt Street]] (now ''Jalan Masjid Kapitan Keling'') to the west, [[Chulia Street, George Town|Chulia Street]] to the south and [[Weld Quay, George Town|Weld Quay]] along the city's eastern shore.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Trade and Society in the Straits of Melaka: Dutch Melaka and English Penang, 1780-1830|last=Nordin Hussin|first=|publisher=National University of Singapore|year=2007|isbn=9789971693541|location=Singapore|pages=|quote=|via=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.penang.gov.my/dmedia/879-penang-investment-seminar|title=Portal Rasmi Kerajaan Negeri Pulau Pinang - Penang Investment Seminar|website=www.penang.gov.my|access-date=2016-11-27}}</ref> [[File:Penang hsbc bank.jpg|thumb|[[Hong Kong and Shanghai Banking Corporation]] (HSBC) Building at [[Beach Street, George Town|Beach Street]], [[George Town, Penang|George Town]]|left]] The CBD therefore covers the several international banks along [[Beach Street, George Town|Beach Street]], such as [[Standard Chartered|Standard Chartered Bank]], [[HSBC]], [[OCBC Bank|Oversea-Chinese Banking Corporation]], [[United Overseas Bank]] and [[Bank of China]], as well as administrative buildings like the [[City Hall, Penang|City Hall]] and the [[Penang State Assembly Building|State Assembly Building]], in a manner similar to the [[Civic District]] within [[Downtown Core|downtown]] [[Singapore]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.thestar.com.my/metro/community/2016/05/17/banking-in-on-preserving-citys-heritage-financial-institutions-centre-made-up-of-three-historical-bu/|title=Banking in on preserving city's heritage - Community {{!}} The Star Online|website=www.thestar.com.my|access-date=2016-11-27}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www1.uob.com.my/uob_branch_locator.html|title=UOB Branch Locator|website=www1.uob.com.my|access-date=2016-11-27}}</ref> The [[City Hall, Penang|City Hall]], built in 1903, houses the head office of the [[Penang Island City Council]], while the [[Penang State Assembly Building|State Assembly Building]] is the meeting place of the [[Penang State Legislative Assembly]].
Due to the numerous Malaysian and international banks that operate within the CBD, [[George Town, Penang|George Town]] serves as the commercial centre for northern [[Malaysia]].
In addition, the CBD serves as a transportation hub within [[George Town, Penang|George Town]]. The city is linked with the [[Malay Peninsula]] via [[Rapid Ferry]], with its [[Raja Tun Uda Ferry Terminal|Ferry Terminal at Weld Quay]]. Right next to the Ferry Terminal is a [[Rapid Penang]] bus terminal, where most bus routes within [[Penang Island]] begin and terminate. == New CBD: [[Northam Road, George Town|Northam]]/[[Gurney Drive, George Town|Gurney]] == [[File:MBF Tower, George Town, Penang.jpg|thumb|The [[MBf Tower]] is one of the oldest commercial skyscrapers along [[Northam Road, George Town|Northam Road]].]] [[File:Gurney Plaza Exterior.jpg|left|thumb|[[Gurney Plaza]], one of the more famous shopping malls in [[Penang]]]]{{see also|Northam Road, George Town|Gurney Drive, George Town}}
In the 1990s, as [[George Town, Penang|George Town]]'s banks began reassessing their spatial requirements to accommodate greater business volumes, a number of commercial developments commenced along [[Northam Road, George Town|Northam Road]].<ref name=":02" /><ref>{{Cite book|title=Modern Dreams: An Inquiry Into Power, Cultural Production and the Cityscape in Contemporary Urban Penang, Malaysia|last=Goh|first=Beng Lan|publisher=SEAP Publications|year=2002|isbn=9780877277309|location=|pages=}}</ref> The commercial skyscrapers along [[Northam Road, George Town|Northam Road]] quickly attracted various banking, auditing and other financial services, as the newer buildings offer more space and amenities that the colonial-era buildings at [[Beach Street, George Town|Beach Street]] lacked. By the early 2000s, [[Northam Road, George Town|Northam Road]] emerged the city's second CBD.
In addition, [[Gurney Drive, George Town|Gurney Drive]], which adjoins [[Northam Road, George Town|Northam Road]] and also has a high concentration of skyscrapers, is now considered as part of [[George Town, Penang|George Town]]'s newer CBD.<ref name=":0" /> Plans have been drawn up to attract financial services to the popular seafront promenade, which already functions as one of the more prominent shopping streets in [[Penang]]. In 2016, the [[Gurney Wharf]] project, which aims to create a seaside recreational park along [[Gurney Drive]], was launched, with land reclamation ongoing off the shoreline.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.asiaone.com/news/malaysia/penangs-gurney-drive-bund-turns-brown-waters-jade-green|title=Penang's Gurney Drive bund turns brown waters jade green|newspaper=AsiaOne|access-date=2016-11-27}}</ref>
The accumulation of financial services along [[Northam Road, George Town|Northam Road]] and [[Gurney Drive, George Town|Gurney Drive]] is partly fueled by the inscription of the city centre as a [[UNESCO]] [[World Heritage Site]] since 2008. The new [[UNESCO]] rulings include a building restriction on construction works exceeding five storeys or 18 metres. As both [[Northam Road, George Town|Northam Road]] and [[Gurney Drive, George Town|Gurney Drive]] lie outside the [[UNESCO]]-protected site, commercial properties along these coastal roads are not impacted by the new building guidelines.

{{For|tendering in the public service|Civil service examination}} {{trade bloc}} '''Government procurement''' or '''public procurement''' is the [[procurement]] of [[Good (economics and accounting)|goods]], [[Service (economics)|services]] and [[construction]] on behalf of a public authority, such as a [[government]] agency. With 10 to 20% of [[GDP]], government procurement accounts for a substantial part of the global economy.<ref>[http://www.cid.harvard.edu/cidtrade/issues/govpro.html Global Trade Negotiations Home Page] at [[Harvard University]], accessed 18 December 2006</ref>
To prevent [[fraud]], [[waste]], [[Political corruption|corruption]], or local [[protectionism]], the laws of most countries regulate government procurement to some extent. Laws usually require the procuring authority to issue public [[Call for bids|tenders]] if the value of the procurement exceeds a certain threshold.
Government procurement is also the subject of the [[Agreement on Government Procurement]] (GPA), a [[plurilateral]] international treaty under the auspices of the [[WTO]].
==Overview==
=== Need for government procurement === Government procurement is necessary because governments cannot produce all the inputs for the goods they provide themselves. Governments usually provide [[public good]]s, e.g. national defense or public infrastructure. Public goods are non-rival and non-excludable, which means that one individual's consumption does not diminish the quantity or quality of the commodity available to others, and individuals cannot be prevented from freely consuming the commodity, or [[Free-rider problem|"free-riding"]]. Consequently, private markets cannot provide public goods. Instead the government provides those goods and finances them by raising taxes from all citizens.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/712588185|title=Economics|last=Mankiw|first=Nicholas Gregory|date=2011|publisher=Cengage Learning|others=Taylor, Mark P. 1958-|year=|isbn=9781844808700|edition= 2nd|location=Andover|pages=223–226|oclc=712588185}}</ref>
In addition to public goods, governments often also provide [[merit good]]s, such as education or health care. Merit goods are [[private good]]s which are rival and excludable and are therefore provided by private markets. Nevertheless, governments also provide merit goods because of reasons of [[Equity (economics)|equity]] and fairness and because they have [[Externality|positive externalities]] for society as a whole.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/39485400|title=Economics of the Public Sector|last=Stiglitz|first=Joseph|date=2000|publisher=W.W. Norton|year=|isbn=0393966518|edition= 3rd|location=New York|pages=86–88|oclc=39485400}}</ref>
In order to provide public and merit goods, the government has to buy input factors from private companies, e.g. police cars, school buildings, uniforms etc. This process is called government or public procurement.
=== Problems === Government procurement involves a high risk of [[corruption]] because of the great size of financial turnover and the complexitiy of many procurement processes in which businesses interact very closely with politicians and civil servants. Often the personal interests of the public officials are not the same as the interests of the public. Such a conflict of interest problem, known as the [[Principal–agent problem|principal-agent-problem]], increases the risk of corruption. According to [[OECD]], the highest percentage of bribery cases occur in the area of public procurement to influence the awarding of public contracts.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.oecd.org/gov/ethics/Corruption-Public-Procurement-Brochure.pdf|title=Preventing Corruption in Public Procurement|last=|first=|date=2016|website=|publisher=OECD|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-06-09}}</ref> Corruption in public procurement causes inefficiencies and high costs to the public. In order to prevent corruption and to ensure transparency and competition among suppliers, public procurement is subject to legal regulation.
===Scope=== Government procurement regulations normally cover all [[public works]], services and supply contracts entered into by a public authority. However, there may be exceptions. These most notably cover [[military acquisition]]s, which account for large parts of government expenditures. The GPA and EU procurement law allow of exceptions where public tendering would violate a country's essential security interests. Additionally, certain politically or economically sensitive sectors, such as public health, energy supply or public transport, may also be treated differently.<ref name="Prieß: Global Overview">{{cite journal|last=Prieß|first=Hans-Joachim|author2=Harvey, Diana|author3=Friton, Pascal|title=Global Overview|journal=Prieß (2012)|pages=3–7}}</ref>
==Regulation by jurisdiction==
===Algeria=== Presidential Decree No. 10-236 of 7 October 2010, supplemented and amended by Presidential Decree No. 12-23 of 18 January 2012, regulate public procurement in [[Algeria]].<ref>Ben Abderrahmane & Partners, [http://www.benlawyers.com/algerian-law/algerian-public-procurement-law-algerian-public-law-144.html Algerian public procurement law - Algerian public law], accessed 1 November 2018</ref>
===American Samoa=== The Office of Procurement, based in [[Tafuna]], is the central authority on procurement for the [[American Samoa]] [[Government of American Samoa|Government]] (ASG), being responsible for the procurement of all construction, goods, and services including the management, control, warehousing, and sale of stores/inventory commodities contained in its warehouse.<ref>American Samoa Government, [https://www.americansamoa.gov/office-of-procurement Office of Procurement]</ref>
===Angola=== Public procurement in [[Angola]] is governed by Law No. 20/10 of 7 September 2010, the Public Procurement Law, and Law No. 2/2011 on Public-Private Partnerships in Angola. The Public Procurement Law repealed Law No. 7/96 of 16 February 1996 and Decree No. 40/05 of 8 June 2005. Public expenditure, the provision of services, the leasing and acquisition of goods, and public works contracts regulated through the Public Procurement Law.<ref>Rodrigues, A. M. and Dias, N. M., [http://www.gla-plmj.com/xms/files/NEW_PRIVATE_INVESTMENT_LAW_CLOSE_TO_ENACTMENT.pdf The New Rules on Public Procurement], published June 2011, accessed 8 November 2016</ref>
===Ascension Island=== All goods required by the [[Ascension Island]] government are purchased through the Ascension Island Government (AIG) Stores, located just outside the [[Georgetown, Ascension Island|Georgetown]] Pier. Goods are also for sale to the general public.<ref>Ascension Island Government, [http://www.ascension-island.gov.ac/government/stores/ Stores], accessed 7 March 2018</ref>
===Australia=== The [[Australian government]]'s procurement activity is governed by the Commonwealth Procurement Rules and overseen by the [[Department of Finance (Australia)|Department of Finance]].<ref>Department of Finance, [https://www.finance.gov.au/procurement/ Procurement], accessed 8 June 2018</ref> The rules were revised on 1 January 2018.<ref>Department of Finance, [https://www.finance.gov.au/procurement/procurement-policy-and-guidance/commonwealth-procurement-rules/ Commonwealth Procurement Rules], accessed 8 June 2018</ref> The Procurement Coordinator is responsible for: *providing external parties with an understanding of the Commonwealth Procurement Framework; *handling of certain procurement-related complaints (although the Procurement Coordinator has no authority to compel a [[List of Australian government entities|government department]] to reconsider the conduct or outcome of tender processes for which that department is responsible);<ref>Procurement Coordinator, [https://www.finance.gov.au/procurement/procurement-coordinator/complaints-handling-charter.html Complaints Handling Charter], 2 October 2014, accessed 10 June 2018</ref> *monitoring issues related to Australian Government procurement; and *reporting to the Minister for Finance on procurement matters where necessary.<ref>Department of Finance, [https://www.finance.gov.au/procurement/procurement-coordinator/ Procurement Coordinator], accessed 8 June 2018</ref>
The Senate Order for Entity Contracts of 20 June 2001 (amended 14 May 2015), also known as the ''[[Andrew Murray (Australian politician)|Murray Motion]]'', requires ministers to publish details of public contracts valued over [[Australian dollar|AUS$]]100,000 on the internet and to table a letter detailing such contracts in the [[Senate (Australia)|Senate]].<ref>[https://www.finance.gov.au/sites/default/files/rmg_403-meeting-the-senate-order-on-entity-contracts.pdf RMG-403: Meeting the Senate Order for Entity Contracts], published February 2017, accessed 8 June 2018</ref>
On 1 December 2016 the House of Representatives and the Senate established a Joint Select Committee to inquire into and report on the Commonwealth Procurement Framework.<ref>Parliament of Australia, [https://www.aph.gov.au/Parliamentary_Business/Committees/Joint/Former_Committees/Government_Procurement Joint Select Committee on Government Procurement], accessed 10 June 2018</ref> The Committee reported in June 2017 recommending a series of amendments to the current Commonwealth Procurement Rules.<ref>Joint Select Committee on Government Procurement, [https://www.aph.gov.au/Parliamentary_Business/Committees/Joint/Former_Committees/Government_Procurement/CommProcurementFramework/Report/section?id=committees%2freportjnt%2f024068%2f24617 ''Buying into our Future'': List of Recommendations], June 2017, accessed 10 June 2018</ref> The Australian government issued a response on 14 November 2017 accepting a number of the recommendations but rejecting others.<ref>Australian Government, [https://www.aph.gov.au/DocumentStore.ashx?id=21281bc3-f2e3-40d9-bf57-46b7a506e3db Australian Government response to the Joint Select Committee on Government Procurement report: Buying into our Future: Review of amendments to the Commonwealth Procurement Rules], 14 November 2017</ref>
[[Infrastructure Australia]] has issued a national [[Public Private Partnership]] (PPP) Policy and set of guidelines on behalf of the federal government, which apply to all PPP projects released in Australia.<ref>DLA Piper, [http://www.dlapiperrealworld.com/law/index.html?t=construction&s=forms-of-contract-procurement-methods&q=public-procurement&c=AU Public procurement in Australia], ''Real World'' website, accessed 8 June 2018</ref>
====Tasmania==== Public bodies in [[Tasmania]] are required to comply with the [[Treasurer of Tasmania|Treasurer]]'s Instructions on Purchasing and Property.<ref>Tasmanian Government, [http://www.treasury.tas.gov.au/purchasing-and-property/purchasing-and-property-treasurers-instructions Purchasing and Property Treasurer's Instructions], accessed 9 July 2018</ref> The [[Department of State Growth (Tasmania)|Department of State Growth]]'s Tasmanian Wood Encouragement Policy has been established to ensure that (where feasible) [[Sustainable development|sustainably]] sourced [[Wood product|wood]] is fully considered within Government procurement decision-making.<ref>Department of State Growth, [http://www.purchasing.tas.gov.au/Documents/Tasmanian-Wood-Encouragement-Policy.pdf Tasmanian Wood Encouragement Policy], May 2017, accessed 9 July 2018</ref><ref>Tasmanian Government, [http://www.treasury.tas.gov.au/Documents/TI-1130.PDF Tasmanian Wood Encouragement Policy - Goods and Services], Treasurer’s Instruction No. 1130, effective 21 July 2017, accessed 9 July 2018</ref>
====Western Australia==== Since 1 July 2018, government departments in [[Western Australia]] have been required to award an increasing percentage of contracts to registered [[Aboriginal Australians|Aboriginal]] businesses under the state's [[Government of Western Australia|government]]'s Aboriginal Procurement Policy.<ref>Government of Western Australia, Department of Finance,[http://www.finance.wa.gov.au/cms/Government_Procurement/Policies/Aboriginal_Procurement_Policy.aspx Aboriginal Procurement Policy], accessed 5 May 2018</ref> The target is 1% of contracts initially, increasing to 2% on 1 July 2019 and 3% on 1 July 2020.<ref>Government of Western Australia, [https://www.mediastatements.wa.gov.au/Pages/McGowan/2017/12/Aboriginal-Procurement-Policy-to-drive-Aboriginal-entrepreneurship-and-business-opportunities.aspx Aboriginal Procurement Policy to drive Aboriginal entrepreneurship and business opportunities], published 19 December 2017, accessed 1 August 2018</ref>
===Bangladesh=== The [[Swiss challenge (procurement)|Swiss Challenge]] system is utilised in [[Bangladesh]] to procure infrastructure development through [[public-private partnerships]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Your Guide to Public Private Partnership in Bangladesh|url=http://www.pppo.gov.bd/download/ppp_office/Your-Guide-to-PPP-in-Bangladesh.pdf|accessdate=3 April 2016}}</ref>
=== Brazil === The procedure of government procurement in Brazil is regulated for a lot of different laws with different procedures depending on the importance and the value of the procurement. The most important law about government procurement which contains basic rules of public procurements and administrative contracts is the Law nº 8.666, 21 june 1993, which contains rules for public tenders and for restricted tenders. There are other different rules to regulate procurement public services, as Law nº 8.987, 13 february 1995 (Concession and Permission of Public Services); Law nº 12.462, 4 august 2011 (Differentiated Procurement - RDC in portuguese) and Law nº 10.520, 17 july 2002, with deal with presential auction. In the internet field (e-procurement) there are executive orders (Decretos) which regulate public procurement as Decree nº 5.450, 31 may 2005 and Decree nº 7.982, 23 january 2013. This latter regulates the procedure of specific situations of sharing acquisitions of goods or under portioned deliverings.<ref>All information can be found in https://www.comprasgovernamentais.gov.br/index.php/legislacao</ref>
===Canada=== Public procurement in Canada is regulated on various governmental levels (federal, provincial, municipal). Most federal procurement is organized by the [[Public Services and Procurement Canada]] (PSPC) agency and is governed by their Code of Conduct of Procurement in combination with principles laid out in the Federal Accountability Act and in the Financial Administration Act. Public procurement is guided by the principles of fairness, transparency, openness, and non-discrimination and complies with all international agreements that Canada is a member of (WTO [[Agreement on Government Procurement|Government Procurement Agreement]] [GPA], [[North American Free Trade Agreement|NAFTA]], [[Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement|CETA]], and various bilateral FTAs). Foreign suppliers from member nations to these agreements can bid on Canadian government procurements and are treated the same as domestic suppliers.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.tpsgc-pwgsc.gc.ca/app-acq/cndt-cndct/contexte-context-eng.html|title=Code of Conduct for Procurement. Context and Purpose of the Code|last=|first=|date=2018-03-09|website=|publisher=Public Works and Government Services Canada|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-06-07}}</ref>
The principal statutory provisions regulating government procurement are:
*Department of Public Works and Government Services Act (1996) *Financial Administration Act (1985) and the Government Contracts Regulations <ref>[http://laws-lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/regulations/SOR-87-402/index.html Government Contracts Regulations], accessed 23 May 2016</ref> *Defence Production Act 1985 (consolidated version published 2011) <ref>[http://www.wipo.int/wipolex/en/text.jsp?file_id=207971 Defence Production Act (R.S.C., 1985, c. D-1) (consolidated version of January 30, 2011)]</ref> *[[Federal Accountability Act|Federal Accountability Act, 2006]] <ref>Public Works and Government Services Canada, [https://buyandsell.gc.ca/policy-and-guidelines/supply-manual/section/1/20 Statutes and Regulations], accessed 23 May 2016</ref>
In general, bids must be solicited by the procuring department unless estimated expenditure does not exceed $25,000, or $100,000 "where the contract is for the acquisition of architectural, engineering and other services required in respect of the planning, design, preparation or supervision of the construction, repair, renovation or restoration of a work".<ref>[http://laws-lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/regulations/SOR-87-402/page-2.html#docCont Government Contracts Regulation 6b], accessed 23 May 2016</ref> For contracts above $25,000, tenders are published on the transparent Government Electronic Tendering Service (GETS). A non-competitive procurement process is only used in certain special circumstances. One such area of exception are security-related procurements. In that case the Defence Production Act applies, which allows using a special process and favouring domestic suppliers in acquiring defence supplies and conducting defence.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://buyandsell.gc.ca/for-businesses/selling-to-the-government-of-canada/the-procurement-process|title=The Procurement Process|last=Engagement|first=Government of Canada, Public Works and Government Services Canada, Acquisitions Branch, Office of Small and Medium Enterprises and Strategic|website=buyandsell.gc.ca|language=en|access-date=2018-06-07}}</ref>
===East Timor=== The Ministry of Finance in [[East Timor]] or Timor-Leste is responsible for the oversight of government procurement.<ref>Ministry of Finance, [https://www.mof.gov.tl/government-procurement/?lang=en Procurement], accessed 13 October 2018</ref> The Government uses the Timor-Leste eProcurement Portal for purchasing.<ref>[http://www.eprocurement.gov.tl/public/indexeprtl?&lang=en Timor-Leste eProcurement Portal]</ref>
===Ethiopia=== Government procurement in [[Ethiopia]] is governed by the Ethiopian Federal Government Procurement and Property Administration Proclamation No.649/2009,<ref name=Eth>[https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B4f0l6J9WQrBYzNmZmJiZjEtYjkyYS00NjhiLWFkMmEtOTA5NjdjMTdkNGEz/view Ethiopian Federal Government Procurement and Property Administration Proclamation], 9 September 2009, accessed 6 November 2011</ref> which replaced the proclamation on Procedures of Public Procurement and Establishing its Supervisory Agency, Proclamation No. 430/2005. The Public Procurement and Property Administration Agency advises the federal government on "on all public procurement and property administration policies, principles and implementation" and provides "technical assistance to the regional governments and city administrations".<ref name=Eth />
===European Union=== {{Main|Government procurement in the European Union}} Government procurement in the European Union accounts for more than EUR 2.2 trillion, or 14% of the EU GDP.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://ec.europa.eu/growth/single-market/public-procurement_en|title=Public Procurement - Growth - European Commission|website=Growth|language=en|access-date=2018-06-07}}</ref> It has been regulated and harmonized by [[European Union law|community law]] since the 1970s in order to guarantee transparency and non-discrimination of EU companies in government procurement in all member states. EU laws apply only to tenders that exceed certain thresholds in value. These thresholds vary depending on the area the contract is for and if the procurement is done by a central government or by other public authorities (e.g. municipal government). National laws are applied for tenders below these threshold values.<ref name="Rules & procedures">{{Cite web|url=https://europa.eu/youreurope/business/public-tenders/rules-procedures/index_en.htm|title=Rules & procedures|website=Your Europe - Business|language=en|access-date=2018-06-07}}</ref> Relevant EU Directives regarding government procurement currently in force are [https://eur-lex.europa.eu/legal-content/EN/TXT/?qid=1415011920358&uri=CELEX:32009L0081 Directive 2009/81], [https://eur-lex.europa.eu/legal-content/en/TXT/?uri=CELEX:32014L0024 Directive 2014/24], and [https://eur-lex.europa.eu/legal-content/en/TXT/?uri=CELEX:32014L0025 Directive 2014/25].
There are five different procedures for public procurement:<ref name="Rules & procedures"/>
*Open procedure: any company is allowed to submit a tender *Restricted procedure: only companies that have been preselected are allowed to submit a tender *Negotiated procedure: there are direct negotiations with at least three companies *Competitive dialogue: if it is not possible to define technical specifications at the beginning, a competitive dialogue with at least three companies is started after which tenders can be submitted. This procedure is applied for complex procurements. *Electronic auctions: companies that pass a pre-evaluation process can bid in electronic auctions for public contracts
The European Commission is working on further improving efficiency and transparency in government procurement in the EU with its current public procurement strategy.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://ec.europa.eu/growth/single-market/public-procurement/strategy_en|title=Public procurement strategy - Growth - European Commission|website=Growth|language=en|access-date=2018-06-07}}</ref>
====Austria==== Government procurement in [[Austria]] is regulated by the Federal Procurement Act 2017.<ref>Stalzer, J., [https://www.schoenherr.eu/publications/publication-detail/austria-imminent-implementation-of-public-procurement-directives/ Austria: Imminent implementation of public procurement directives], accessed 14 March 2018</ref>
====Belgium==== [[Belgium|Belgian]] legislation on public procurement is set out in the Act of 17 June 2016 implementing the 2014 EU procurement directives.<ref>International Comparative Legal Guide, [https://iclg.com/practice-areas/public-procurement-laws-and-regulations/belgium Public Procurement 2018: Belgium], accessed 27 March 2018</ref> The Laws of 17 June 2016 on public procurement and on concession contracts, and the Law of 16 February 2017 on remedies, failed to meet the EU's transposition deadline (18 April 2016). [[Royal order (Belgium)|Royal Decree]]s issued on 18 April 2017 for general public procurement, 18 June 2017 for procurement in the water, energy, transport and postal services sectors, 22 June 2017 containing new rules on the performance of public works contracts and concession contracts for public works and 25 June 2017, for the award and performance of concession contracts, have augmented the earlier laws.<ref name=vbb>Van Bael and Bellis, [https://www.vbb.com/media/Insights_Articles/VBB_Memorandum_Public_Procurement_27_07_2017.pd.pdf New Belgian Regulatory Framework Governing Public Procurement – Overview of Main Novelties], accessed 29 October 2018</ref>
Article 51 of the Royal Decree of 18 April 2017 includes a "revolving door mechanism", which targets the situation where a person previously working for a contracting authority is now being employed by an economic operator involved in a public procurement procedure established by that contracting authority. In this type of situation the person would be presumed to have a [[conflict of interest]] for a two-year period following the termination of his/her employment with the contracting authority.<ref name=vbb />
====Bulgaria==== Government procurement in Bulgaria is a critical area in corruption risk. Public procurement contracts have been awarded to a handful of companies amid widespread irregularities, procedure violations and tailor-made selection or award criteria.<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://ec.europa.eu/regional_policy/sources/policy/how/improving-investment/public-procurement/study/country_profile/bg.pdf|title=Public procurement in Bulgaria|work=Study on administrative capacity in the EU|publisher=European Commission|accessdate=16 July 2018}}</ref> The Bulgarian public procurement portal reported in September 2016 that since the beginning of 2016, "a total of 15,105 contracts were signed on the basis of public procurement orders".<ref>Sofia News Agency, [http://www.novinite.com/articles/176510/15%2C105+Public+Procurement+Contracts+Signed+So+Far+in+2016 15,105 Public Procurement Contracts Signed So Far in 2016], accessed 1 October 2016</ref> At the beginning of 2015, the [[Bulgarian government]] announced a 130-kilometer extension to the barbed wire [[Bulgarian border barrier|border fence]] along its border with [[Turkey]] in order to completely secure the land border. Prime Minister [[Boyko Borisov]] described the extension as "absolutely necessary" in order to prevent persons from [[Illegal immigration|illegally]] entering the European Union member state.<ref>{{cite web|title= Bulgaria to extend fence at Turkish border to bar refugee influx |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2015/01/14/us-bulgaria-turkey-fence-idUSKBN0KN1JG20150114 |accessdate=April 12, 2015}}</ref> The [[Bulgarian Parliament]] authorised amendments to procurement legislation to allow continued construction of the fence without launching a public procurement procedure "because of the need to safeguard national security".<ref>{{cite web|title= Parliament OKs Building of Border Fence Without Public Procurement |url=http://www.novinite.com/articles/166066/Parliament+OKs+Building+of+Border+Fence+Without+Public+Procurement |accessdate=April 12, 2015}}</ref> Overall,
====Croatia==== The first public procurement law in [[Croatia]] based on the EU Procurement Directives was enacted in 2001, but a revised legal structure for public procurement was put in place with the Public Procurement Act of 2012,<ref name=HR>European Commission, [http://ec.europa.eu/regional_policy/sources/policy/how/improving-investment/public-procurement/study/country_profile/hr.pdf Public procurement – Study on administrative capacity in the EU: Croatia Country Profile]</ref> and this was superseded by the Public Procurement Act of 2016, effective 1 January 2017.<ref>Tematikon Project, [http://www.tematikon.com/en/review/published-new-public-procurement-act-16 Published new Public Procurement Act], accessed 23 May 2018</ref> Public-private partnerships (PPPs) are governed by the Act on Public-Private Partnerships.<ref>DLA Piper, [http://www.dlapiperrealworld.com/law/index.html?t=construction&s=forms-of-contract-procurement-methods&q=public-procurement&c=HR Public procurement], accessed 23 May 2018</ref> Two key Croatian institutions are the Public Procurement Office and the Public Procurement Supervisory Commission, established in 2001,<ref>Madir, J. and Rimac, L.,[http://www.ebrd.com/downloads/research/law/lit113h.pdf Croatia: reforms to meet the terms of the EU ''acquis''], accessed 12 May 2018</ref> now (since 2013) the State Commission for Supervision of Public Procurement (DKOM).<ref name=HR /> The State Commission is an independent quasi-judicial body with nine members appointed by the [[Croatian Parliament]] for a five-year term and accountable to the Croatian Parliament for its work. The High Administrative Court of the Republic of Croatia has jurisdiction over the State Commission in relation to disputes concerning procedure, but there is no right of appeal against Commission decisions.<ref>State Commission for Supervision of Public Procurement, [http://www.dkom.hr/en/about-us/1197 About us], accessed 23 May 2018</ref>
Under [[Croatian law]], procurement procedures must be carried out by authorised representatives of the contracting authority, of whom at least one must hold a valid procurement certificate.
====Cyprus==== The Public Procurement Directorate of the Treasury of the [[Republic of Cyprus]] is responsible for procurement policy.<ref>Treasury of the Republic, [http://www.treasury.gov.cy/treasury/PublicPro/ppro.nsf/dmlindex_en/dmlindex_en Public Procurement], accessed 24 May 2018</ref>
====Czech Republic==== Government procurement in the [[Czech Republic]] is regulated by Act No. 134/2016 Coll., on Public Contracts, signed by the [[President of the Czech Republic|President of the Republic]] on 22 April 2016.<ref>Zeman, M., [http://law.vozab.com/czech-en/168-new-act-no-134-2016-coll-on-public-procurement New act no. 134/2016 Coll. on public procurement], Vozáb & Co., accessed 16 June 2018</ref>
====Denmark==== [[Economic operator]]s who are dissatisfied with the conduct of public procurement activity in [[Denmark]] may complain to the Klagenævnet for Udbud (Public Procurement Complaints Board).
====Estonia==== The [[Estonia]]n [[Ministry of Finance (Estonia)|Ministry of Finance]] is responsible for public procurement policy, drafting the law, providing supervision and consultancy, and maintains a central Public Procurement Register.<ref>Ministry of Finance, [https://riigihanked.riik.ee/register/ E-Procurement Estonia: Procurement Register], accessed 14 June 2018</ref> The current legislation is the Public Procurement Act of 2017, which came into effect on 1 September 2017,<ref>Riigi Teataja, [https://www.riigiteataja.ee/en/eli/505092017003/consolide Public Procurement Act 2017], accessed 14 June 2018</ref> and which operates in conjunction with the Public Information Act of 2000, which regulates the publication of "information concerning public procurements which are being organised or have been organised by the state or local governments".<ref>Riigi Teataja, [https://www.riigiteataja.ee/en/eli/514112013001/consolide Public Information Act 2000], section 28(1)(20)</ref> Disputes are handled by the Public Procurements Appeal Committee.
Defence procurement for the Defence Forces, [[Ministry of Defence (Estonia)|Ministry of Defence]], [[Estonian Defence League|Defence League]], Defence Resources Agency and Estonian War Museum is organised by the Estonian Centre for Defence Investment, whose purpose is "to carry out procurement activities through ... professional-quality procurement and to use dedicated funds sparingly and prudently".<ref>[http://www.kaitseministeerium.ee/en/organisation-contacts/centre-defence-investments/defence-procurement Defence Procurement], accessed 2 June 2018</ref> The Centre for Defence Investment was established by the decree of the Minister of Defence on 9 November 2015 and became operational on 1 January 2017.<ref>[http://www.kaitseministeerium.ee/en/organisation-contacts/centre-defence-investment Centre for Defence Investment], accessed 2 June 2018</ref>
====Finland==== In [[Finland]] the following legislation applies to government procurement: *Act on Public Contracts and Concession Contracts (Act no. 1397 of 2016, effective 1 January 2017) <ref>Ministry of Economic Affairs and Employment, [http://www.finlex.fi/en/laki/kaannokset/2016/en20161397.pdf Act on Public Procurement and Concession Contracts], accessed 31 July 2018</ref> *Act on Public Contracts by Contracting Authorities in the Water, Energy, Transport and Postal Services Sectors (Act no. 1398 of 2016, also known as the 'Act on public contracts in special sectors') *Act on Public Contracts in the Fields of Defence and Security.<ref>[https://www.kkv.fi/en/facts-and-advice/competition-affairs/supervision-of-public-procurement/ Supervision of Public Procurement], accessed 30 July 2018</ref><ref name=Finland>The Law Reviews, [https://thelawreviews.co.uk/edition/the-government-procurement-review-edition-4/1136567/finland The Government Procurement Review, Issue 4 - Finland], accessed 11 July 2018</ref>
A Government Decree on Public Contracts was also in force until 2017.<ref name=Finland />
The [[Ministry of Economic Affairs and Employment (Finland)|Ministry of Employment and the Economy]] is responsible for the preparation of legislation concerning public procurement. The Finnish Competition and Consumer Authority (FCCA) oversees public procurement: section 139 of the Act on Public Procurement and Concession Contracts mandates the FCCA to supervise compliance with public contracts legislation and to provide 'administrative guidance' or if necessary to issue a caution to a non-compliant public authority.<ref>FCCA, [https://www.kkv.fi/en/current-issues/press-releases/2018/26.6.2018-fcca-reprimands-riihimaki-and-vaasa-for-failing-to-invite-tenders-for-procurement-contracts/ FCCA reprimands Riihimäki and Vaasa for failing to invite tenders for procurement contracts], published 6 June 2018, accessed 31 July 2018</ref> The Market Court operates as a specialist court handling public procurement cases. The Market Court's rulings in public procurement cases can be appealed to the [[Supreme Administrative Court of Finland]].<ref name=Finland />
The Act on Electronic Auctions and Dynamic Purchasing Systems of 17 June 2011, which entered into force on 1 October 2011, introduced new procurement procedures, whereby documents relating to procurement would be sent and received exclusively online. This legislation included the use of [[Eauction|eAuction]]s.<ref>European Commission, [https://joinup.ec.europa.eu/sites/default/files/document/2014-06/eGov%20in%20FI%20-%20May%202014%20-%2016.0.pdf eGovernment in Finland, May 2014], accessed 31 July 2018</ref> Electronic procurement is now covered within the 2016 Act on Public Contracts.
Transposition of the 2014 EU public procurement directive into Finnish law was delayed after the deadline (18 April 2016) with the consequence that some aspects of the directive were directly applicable from April 2016 until the new Finnish legislation was in place from 1 January 2017.<ref>Merilampi, [http://www.merilampi.com/the-reform-of-the-act-on-public-contracts-the-finnish-legislation-is-delayed/?lang=en The reform of the Act on Public Contracts – the Finnish legislation is delayed], published 28 April 2016, accessed 27 July 2018</ref>
[[Hansel Ltd.]] is a state-owned central purchasing body established by the ''Act on a Limited Liability Company Called Hansel Oy'', which operates framework agreements and supports central government departments in Finland with public procurement tasks.<ref>[https://www.hansel.fi/en/framework-agreements/ Hansel - Framework Agreements], accessed 31 July 2018</ref>
==== France ==== In France, the Department of Legal Affairs (DAJ) of the [[French Ministry for the Economy and Finance|Ministry for the Economy and Finance]] ([[French language|French]]: ''Ministère de l'Économie et des Finances'') is responsible for establishing regulations regarding public procurement (''la commande publique''). All currently relevant EU directives have been implemented into national law.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.economie.gouv.fr/daj/commande-publique|title=Commande publique|work=Le portail des ministères économiques et financiers|access-date=2018-06-09|language=fr}}</ref>
The ''Union des Groupements d’Achat Public'' (UGAP), based in [[Champs-sur-Marne]] east of Paris,<ref>[https://www.ugap.fr/ l'UGAP] (in French)</ref> operates as the only general public procurement agency in France.<ref>[https://www.cgi.com/en/CGI-selected-UGAP-France-national-procurement-agency-bring-consulting-IT-skills-public-sector CGI selected by UGAP, France’s national procurement agency, to bring its consulting and IT skills to the public sector], 4 February 2013, accessed 1 August 2018</ref>
==== Germany ==== In Germany, the [[Federal Ministry for Economic Affairs and Energy]] ([[German language|German]]: ''Bundesministerium für Wirtschaft und Energie'', abbreviated BMWi) is responsible for defining laws and principles regarding public procurement. In 2016 Germany transposed the new EU Directives of 2014 into domestic law. Thereby, processes and contracts in public procurement have become easier and more flexible. The Act against Restraints of Competition - Part IV (German: ''[[:de:Gesetz gegen Wettbewerbsbeschränkungen|Gesetz gegen Wettbewerbsbeschränkungen]]'', abbreviated GWB) and the Ordinance on the Award of Public Contracts (German: [[:de:Vergabeverordnung|V''erordnung über die Vergabe öffentlicher Aufträge'']], abbreviated VgV) regulate procurement above EU thresholds. Detailed procedures are specified in further regulations, e.g. the Procurement Regulation for Public Works (German abbreviation: [[:de:Vergabe- und Vertragsordnung für Bauleistungen|VOB]]), the Procurement Regulation for Public Supplies and Services ([[:de:Vergabe- und Vertragsordnung für Leistungen|VOL]]), and the Procurement Regulation for Professional Services ([[:de:Vergabeordnung für freiberufliche Leistungen|VOF]]).<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bmwi.de/Redaktion/EN/Dossier/public-procurement.html|title=Public Procurement|last=|first=|date=|website=Federal Ministry for Economic Affairs and Energy|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-06-07}}</ref> For many contracts electronic procurement is made possible via an [https://www.evergabe-online.de/start.html?0 online platform].
For public procurement below the EU thresholds there are different regulations. At the federal level national budgetary law applies while the 16 federal German states and some municipalities have their own public procurement laws and regulations. This decentralized system reflects the political decentralization in Germany. However, sub-national level procurement regulations often take national regulations as examples and also ensure competition, non-discrimination, and transparency.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://ec.europa.eu/regional_policy/sources/policy/how/improving-investment/public-procurement/study/country_profile/de.pdf|title=Public Procurement - Germany Country Profile|last=|first=|date=|website=European Commission|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-06-07}}</ref>
====Gibraltar==== Government procurement in [[Gibraltar]] is managed by the Procurement Office, an independent office of [[Her Majesty's Government of Gibraltar|Her Majesty's Government of Gibraltar]] which reports directly to the Financial Secretary.<ref>Government of Gibraltar, [https://gibraltar.gov.gi/new/procurement-office Procurement Office], accessed 5 July 2016</ref>
====Greece==== Law 4412/2016 on public procurement and Law 4413/2016 on concessions are the main instruments of [[Greece|Greek]] legislation governing public procurement. These two laws of 2016, along with earlier reforms introduced under Law 4281/2014 on public procurement law, have radically simplified the previously complex legal regime, repealing numerous previous laws.<ref>International Comparative Legal Guides, [https://iclg.com/practice-areas/public-procurement-laws-and-regulations/greece Public Procurement 2018: Greece], published 26 January 2018, accessed 6 August 2018</ref> The European Commission's profile for [[Greece]] in its study of administrative capacity in the EU had described the public procurement system in the country as "singularly complex, ... being dispersed among as many as 400 laws, regulations, and presidential decrees".<ref name=profile>[http://ec.europa.eu/regional_policy/sources/policy/how/improving-investment/public-procurement/study/country_profile/el.pdf Public procurement – Study on administrative capacity in the EU: Greece Country Profile]</ref> Public contract notices are published in the Central Electronic Registry for Public Procurement (KIMDIS).<ref>[https://www.unodc.org/documents/treaties/UNCAC/WorkingGroups/workinggroup4/2016-August-22-24/Contributions_NV/Greece_EN.pdf Hellenic Single Public Procurement Authority], accessed 6 August 2018</ref>
The Public Procurement Monitoring Unit (PPMU), established in 1997, part of the Centre of International and European Economic Law in [[Thessaloniki]], provides Greek contracting authorities with "specialised and prompt legal advisory support on awarding public works and technical services contracts falling within the scope of EU Law on Public Procurement".<ref name=profile /><ref>[http://mopadis.cieel.gr/index.jsp?extLang=LG Public Procurement Monitoring Unit: Welcome], accessed 6 August 2018</ref>
====Hungary==== The [[Hungary|Hungarian]] Public Procurement Authority was established by Act XL of 1995 <ref>[http://www.kozbeszerzes.hu/english/ Public Procurement Authority of Hungary]</ref> and the current Public Procurement Act (Act CXLIII of 2015) entered into force on November 1, 2015, implementing the 2014 EU procurement directives.<ref name=cxliii>[https://www.procurementinet.org/wp-content/uploads/2017/02/Public-Procurement-Act-Hungary.pdf Act CXLIII of 2015 on Public Procurement], accessed 13 August 2018</ref> The objectives of the 2015 legislation are: *to secure transparency and public control of the effective use of public funds; *to establish conditions of fair competition in public procurement; *to enhance the access of local small and medium-sized enterprises to procurement procedures; and *to promote environmental protection and the social considerations of the State.<ref name=cxliii /> Concession award procedures are also covered within the same legislation, and the fundamental principles set out in Act V of 2013 on the [[Civil Code]], the "ultimate instrument relating to the operation of civil persons and economic organizations", also apply to public procurement.<ref>Borsy Association of Lawyers, [http://borsyugyveditarsulas.hu/en/magyar-az-uj-polgari-torvenykonyvrol/ The New Civil Code of Hungary], accessed 13 August 2018</ref>
====Ireland==== Government procurement in [[Ireland]] is governed by the European Communities (Award of Public Authorities' Contracts) Regulations 2006 <ref>[http://etenders.gov.ie/Media/Default/SiteContent/LegislationGuides/Public%20Sector%20Procurement%20Regulations%202006.pdf S.I. No. 329 of 2006: European Communities (Award of Public Authorities’ Contracts) Regulations 2006]</ref> and the European Communities (Public Authorities’ Contracts) (Review Procedures) Regulations 2010. [[Patrick O'Donovan|Patrick O’Donovan TD]] is the [[Ministers of State of the 32nd Dáil|Minister of State]] with special responsibility for Public Procurement.<ref>Office of Government Procurement, [http://ogp.gov.ie/wp-content/uploads/ogp-newsletterfeb2018.pdf OGP News], February 2018, accessed 2 April 2018</ref>
==== Italy ==== Public procurement in [[Italy]] is primarily regulated by the Public Contracts Code, which is administered by the [[Ministry of Infrastructure and Transport (Italy)|Ministry of Infrastructure and Transport]] ([[Italian language|Italian]]: Ministero delle infrastrutture e dei trasporti). The code was reformed in 2016 to implement the new EU directives of 2014 into domestic Italian law.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.mit.gov.it/en/comunicazione/news/new-public-procurement-and-concession-contracts-code-has-entered-force|title=The new Public Procurement and Concession Contracts Code has entered into force {{!}} mit|last=|first=|date=2016-04-15|website=www.mit.gov.it|publisher=Italian Ministry of Transport and Infrastructure|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-06-09}}</ref> In addition to the code, guidelines from the [[National Anti-Corruption Authority (Italy)|National Anti-Corruption Authority]] (Italian: ''Autorità Nazionale AntiCorruzione,'' abbreviated ANAC) and decrees from various ministries also apply to public procurement. Most public procurement on a national level is administered by the state-owned company [[Consip|Consip S.p.A.]] Larger regions have their own agencies for public purchasing.
The five regions with special autonomy ([[Friuli-Venezia Giulia]], [[Sardinia]], [[Sicily]], [[Trentino-Alto Adige/Südtirol|Trentino-Alto Adige]], [[Aosta Valley|Valle d’Aosta]]) can also establish regional legislation regarding public procurement.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://ec.europa.eu/regional_policy/sources/policy/how/improving-investment/public-procurement/study/country_profile/it.pdf|title=Public procurement - Italy Country Profile|last=|first=|date=|website=European Commission|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-06-09}}</ref>
====Latvia==== Government procurement in [[Latvia]] is regulated by the Public Procurement Law, effective 1 March 2017, and the Law on the Procurement of Public Service Providers, which came into effect on 1 April 2017. These laws transpose the EU procurement directives; one additional legal provision is that for supplier selection purposes, [[real estate]] tax debts are checked where tenderers are registered or permanently resident in Latvia. Public procurement opportunities are advertised on the Latvian ''Elektronisko Iepirkumu Sistēma'' (EIS) website.<ref>[https://www.eis.gov.lv/EIS/ Elektronisko Iepirkumu Sistēma], accessed 25 August 2018</ref>
The Procurement Monitoring Office within the [[Government institutions in Latvia#Ministry of Finance|Ministry of Finance]] oversees public procurement.<ref>Gencs Valters Law Firm, [https://baltic-lawfirm.eu/de/service-news/public-procurement-lv.html Public Procurement in Latvia], accessed 25 August 2018</ref> A deposit for filing a review application with the Procurement Monitoring Office must be paid, calculated as 0.5% of the estimated contract value, but no more than €15,000 for construction work contracts or €840 for supply and public service contracts.<ref>Tark Grunte Sutkiene, [http://tgsbaltic.com/news/knowledge/public-procurement-alert-the-new-public-procurement-law-comes-into-force-in-latvia Public Procurement Alert: The new Public Procurement Law Comes Into Force In Latvia], accessed 25 August 2018</ref>
